intro: Hypericum gramineum var. genuinum, commonly known as the narrowleaf St. John's wort, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, upright stems covered in small, yellow-orange flowers. The plant has linear, grass-like leaves that are often arranged in whorls around the stem. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained, sandy or loamy soils. Its flowering period occurs in late summer, producing clusters of four-petaled flowers that attract pollinators like bees and butterflies.
